Further, cyberspace capabilities and operations parallel those in the physical domain, but cyber represents a different technical application in an attempt to achieve some of the exact same effects. Additionally, the development of cyber weapons represents the next evolutionary step in warfare, so it possesses all of the ethical concerns posed by similar weapons developed in the past. Therefore, the United States places great importance on maintaining compliance with LOAC even though cyber capabilities and operations were not planned for by the LOAC founders.\n## B. The Objects of Cyber Attacks\nThe Tallinn Manual also discusses who may be made the object of cyber-attacks and lists them as: 1) members of the armed forces; 2) members of organized armed groups; 3) civilians taking a direct part in hostilities; and 4) participants in a *levée en masse* during an international armed conflict. It should be noted that the first two categories can be made the object of an attack based on their status; however, the last two categories can only be made targets based on their actions. Members of organized armed\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n Patrick Tucker, *NSA Chief: Rules of War Apply to Cyberwar*, Too, DEF. ONE (Apr. 20, 2015), http://cdn.defenseone.com/defenseone/interstitial.html?v=2.1.1&amp;rf=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.defenseone.com%2Ftechnology%2F2015%2F04%2Fnsa-chief-rules-war-apply-cyberwar-too%2F110572%2F [https://perma.cc/8RJM-ZLQT].\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n Geneva POW, *supra* note 34, art. 4.\n\ngroups are defined differently from different sources. The Tallinn Manual’s International Group of Experts were split over whether mere membership in such a group suffices or whether members would be required to show a continuous combat function. The continuous combat function is a requirement provided by the International Committee of the Red Cross in its guidance. This guidance requires the organized armed group to belong to a party to the conflict, demonstrated by conducting hostilities on behalf and with the agreement of the party. Further, members of the organized armed groups demonstrate their membership only by assuming continuous functions for the group, which involves direct participation in hostilities.\nThe second two categories of individuals who can be made the object of a cyber-attack are civilians who directly participate in hostilities, which will be addressed below, and participants in a levée en masse during an international armed conflict. Inhabitants of unoccupied territory during an international armed conflict who engage in cyber operations as part of a levée en masse are afforded combatant immunity and prisoner of war status. In addition, participants in a cyber-based levée en masse are targetable throughout the period of their participation therein. To be considered a levée en masse, the participating individuals must be inhabitants of non-occupied territory, who upon the invading enemy’s approach, take up arms to resist them. In the cyber context, “taking up arms” refers to engaging in cyber operations against the enemy.\nThis “taking up arms” in cyberspace is theoretical based on the facts that would have to exist for a cyber levée en masse to be\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n Nils Melzer, *Interpretive Guidance on the Notion of Direct Participation Under International Humanitarian Law*, INT’L COMM. RED CROSS 1, 37 (2009), https://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/other/icrc-002-0990.pdf [https://perma.cc/N8G8-BMSB] (explaining particular difficulties relating to private contractors and civilian employees).\n *Id.* at Part I, 2, b.\n *Id.* at Part II, 1.\n TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 27.\n *Id.* at Rule 34, comment 9.\n *Id.* at Rule 27.\n *Id.*\n\n[Vol. XLII]\nlawfully carried out. In the physical world, the levée en masse occurs when the enemy invades, and the inhabitants take on arms to defend themselves without being organized. However, this levée en masse is still required to carry arms openly and respect the laws and customs of war, though they are not required to wear identifying attire. In the cyber domain, a levée en masse could occur if, in response to a physical invasion, members of the population spontaneously mount cyber operations against the invaders. Further, the International Group of Experts are divided as to whether levée en masse privileges can apply to a civilian population engaged in countering a massive cyber-attack in lieu of a physical invasion.\nIn general, civilians should be protected in the cyberspace domain in much the same way as they are protected in the physical domains. The difference is the virtually untested nature of the cyberspace domain. It remains unclear exactly how States are to behave in cyberspace, what rises to the level of a cyber-attack, and what level of physical domain response is authorized for a particular cyber-attack. These and other unresolved translations from the physical realm to the cyber domain make difficult the protection of civilians during an international armed conflict. A step further would be the impact on civilians when they decide to directly participate in cyber hostilities.\n## IV. Civilians Directly Participating in Hostilities in the Cyberspace Domain\nThe Tallinn Manual provides that, based on LOAC principles, there is no bar of any category of person from participating in cyber operations, whether during an international or non-international armed conflict. However, civilians participating in an armed conflict through cyber operations would likely not be entitled to prisoner of war status and combatant immunity, and they could be targeted based on their participation. The\n *Id.*\n Geneva POW, *supra* note 34, art. 4.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 25.\n *Id.* at Rule 25, comment 2.\n\nentitlement to combatant immunity and prisoner of war status are dependent upon the individual being engaged in an international armed conflict, as opposed to solely a non-international armed conflict or actions not rising to the level of armed conflict. Even if civilians participate in hostilities, the majority of the International Group of Experts agree that civilians retain their civilian status. However, civilians remain subject to prosecution under the applicable domestic laws of the States capturing them.\n## A. Defining Direct Participation in Hostilities\nAs previously mentioned, civilians can be made the object of cyber-attacks if they are directly taking part in hostilities. Though civilians are protected from attack during international armed conflicts, they lose that protection if and for so long as they directly participate in hostilities. This protection from attack and subsequent loss of protection only applies to civilians; it does not apply to members of armed forces, organized armed groups, or participants in a *levée en masse*. Further, members of groups failing to qualify as organized armed groups would also qualify as civilians under this rule. For example, a group would fail to be recognized as an organized armed group if they lack the required level of organization or if they fail to maintain a continuous combat function.\nConducting operations in cyberspace that may rise to the level of direct participation in hostilities can be better understood by looking at the functions or tasks carried out in the cyber domain. Those involved in cyber operations seemingly fall in to three main categories according to their functions: 1) those who design or write the programs used for offense or defensive cyber operations; 2) those who install these programs on computer systems, act as service administrators, and provide technical maintenance; and 3)\n *Id.* at Rule 25.\n *Id.* at Rule 29.\n *Id.* at Rule 29.\n *Id.* at Rules 32, 35.\n Geneva POW, *supra* note 34, art. 4; TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 35.\n *Id.*\n *Id.* art. 4; Melzer, *supra* note 90, at Part I.2.b.\n\n[Vol. XLII\nthose who actually operate the computer programs. A lone civilian could presumably be filling all of these roles in a solo operation.\nWhen civilians directly participate in hostilities through cyber operations during an international armed conflict, they are liable to be attacked either through cyber means or other lawful means under LOAC. IHL does not define direct participation in hostilities, so direct participation must be interpreted in good faith according to the ordinary meaning and the context based on the object and purpose of IHL. Treaty law in this area refers to hostilities in terms of international or non-international armed conflict, so that should be the threshold; hostilities cannot refer to internal disturbances, riots, or isolated and sporadic events. Not all conduct during an armed conflict constitutes part of hostilities. Civilian participation in hostilities can occur in various forms and intensity levels in a wide variety of geographical, cultural, political, and military contexts, so the circumstances at the relevant time and place of the hostilities should be examined.\nThe direct participation in hostilities refers to specific acts, which are carried out by individuals as part of the hostilities between two parties in an armed conflict. There are therefore two elements: 1) direct participation; and 2) hostilities. Participation in hostilities can either be direct or indirect; direct participation is the engagement in specific hostile acts. The concept of hostilities is best described as the aggregate of all hostile acts carried out by all individuals, either armed forces, organized armed groups, or civilians, during an armed conflict.\nThe specific acts carried out by civilians qualify as direct participation in hostilities if they meet all of the following criteria:\n Cyber, supra note 57.\n Geneva POW, supra note 34, art. 4; TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, at Rule 35.\n Melzer, supra note 90, at Part II.B.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id. at Part VI.\n Id.\n Melzer, supra note 90, at Part VI.\n\n1) the act is likely to adversely affect the military operations or capacity of a party to an armed conflict or inflict death, injury, or destruction on persons or objects protected against direct attack, which is the threshold of harm; 2) there must be a direct causal link between the act and harm that is likely to occur from the act; and 3) the act must be specifically designed to directly cause the required threshold of harm in support of a party to the armed conflict. The threshold of harm is based on likely harm and does not require the act to materialize into the expected level of harm. Additionally, the act does not have to be an actual attack against troops or military objects; it also includes acts of sabotage as well as disturbing deployments and communications.\nIn addition to meeting the threshold of harm, the second criterion requires there also be a direct causal link between the act and the harm. For there to be direct causation, there must be a sufficiently close causal relationship between the act and the resulting harm. Specifically, direct causation should be brought about in one causal step. Individual actions that can be viewed as merely supporting one side to an armed conflict or that only build up or maintain the capacity of a party is excluded from the concept of direct participation in hostilities. For example, providing supplies for a party or financing the actions of a party to an armed conflict would bring about a result, but there is not direct causation for the potential harm. Other examples of indirect participation would be scientific research and design, recruitment and the training of personnel, and the production or transportation of weapons or equipment.\nThe third criterion requires there be a belligerent nexus, which is that an act must be specifically designed to directly cause the required threshold of harm in support of a party to the armed conflict. Accordingly, the act must be objectively likely to inflict harm, and it must be specifically designed to do so in\n *Id.* at Part V.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.* at Part V.2.b.\n *Id.* at Part V.2.f.\n Melzer, *supra* note 90, at Part V.\n *Id.* at Part V.2.b.\n *Id.* at Part V.3.\n\n[Vol. XLII]\nsupport of a party to the armed conflict. Therefore, violence that is not designed to harm a party to an armed conflict cannot amount to direct participation in hostilities. This type of violence is left solely to domestic law enforcement measures and not LOAC or IHL. The belligerent nexus requirement is important, because there are many activities during armed conflict that cause a considerable level of harm but fall short of direct participation in hostilities. This is exemplified by violent crimes committed for reasons unrelated to the conflict, such as robberies or murders, as well as the theft of military equipment for private use or sale. Also requiring special attention is use of individual self-defense or defense of others. If a civilian uses force to protect his property from looting, he is not doing so with a belligerent nexus. Instead, he is acting out of self-defense.\nUnderstanding whether hostilities by civilians during armed conflict rise to the level of direct participation is not enough. The defining moment of when the direct participation in hostilities begins and ends is also important. Preparatory measures leading up to the execution of the specific act, and the movement to and from the location of the execution, all constitute integral parts of the act. Accordingly, IHL concerns itself with more than just exactly when the act took place; it looks at the totality of the circumstances surrounding the civilian’s direct participation in hostilities. This is a significant point, because civilians lose their protection against direct attacks for such time as they directly participate in hostilities.\nPreparatory measures are those that IHL would describe as military operations in preparation for an attack and which are so closely linked to the execution of the specific act that they constitute an integral part of the act. Even so, there is no requirement that the preparatory measures occur immediately prior to the specific act or even in close geographic proximity to the\n\nplace of the specific act. An example in the physical domain would be a civilian who builds a bomb in his garage, which he intends to place in the road in order to blow it up and injure armed forces during an international armed conflict. In this illustration, the preparatory measures taken by the civilian bomb maker in his garage, as well as the transit to and from the place where he plants the bomb, would all be considered part of the direct participation in hostilities. Thus, the bomb maker could be targeted at any point from when he starts building the bomb in his garage until he returns home from planting it. Also included in general preparatory measures would be the transporting of personnel, gathering of intelligence, and equipping and instructing armed forces. Where the execution of a hostile act does not require deployment, such as hostilities in cyberspace, the duration of the act should be limited to the immediate execution of the act.\n## B. Tallinn Manual View of Direct Participation in Hostilities\nThe Tallinn Manual’s International Group of Experts generally agrees with the three cumulative criteria for qualification as a direct participation in hostilities as applied to cyberspace. First, there must be a threshold of harm, wherein the civilian has the intended or actual effect of negatively affecting the military operations or capabilities of a party to an armed conflict or inflicting death, physical harm, or material destruction on persons or objects protected against direct attack. Physical damage to objects or harm to individuals is not required, so long as the cyber act negatively affects the party militarily. Second, there must be a direct causal link between the act and the harm intended. An example would be a civilian conducting cyber acts against an armed force in international armed conflict, wherein the civilian disrupts the command and control, even temporarily, for the armed force. Finally, there must be a belligerent nexus established by the\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n Melzer, *supra* note 90, at Part VI.\n TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 35, comment 4.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n\n[Vol. XLII\nact directly relating to the hostilities.\nIn cyberspace, direct participation in hostilities by civilians may be more difficult to delineate. Determining whether a civilian directly participated in conventional hostilities is complex by itself; making the same determination in cyber-hostilities is especially so. Civilians conducting cyber-attacks related to an armed conflict would qualify as an act of direct participation in hostilities. A cyber-attack is defined as a cyber operation that is reasonably expected to cause injury or death to persons or damage or destruction to objects. Accordingly, civilians conducting cyber-attacks in this way would meet the three criteria for directly participating in hostilities. Other examples of direct participation include civilians conducting cyber operations with the intent to identify vulnerabilities in a targeted computer network or system, or civilians designing malware to take advantage of vulnerabilities in the systems of a party to an armed conflict. Further examples in the cyber domain include civilians using cyber means to gather information on enemy operations and passing that information to the other armed force in the conflict as well as conducting distributed denial of service operations against military systems.\nOn the other hand, not all cyber operations by civilians would rise to the level of direct participation in hostilities. For example, designing malware for a specific purpose and making it available online, even if it is actually used by someone else to conduct an attack during an armed conflict, would not be considered direct participation. What would be lacking would be the threshold of harm in the first criterion; the malware creator never had the intended or actual effect of negatively affecting military operations or capabilities. Another example would be civilians simply maintaining computer equipment generally, even if that equipment were eventually used in hostilities. Again, what would be\n *Id.*\n Emily Crawford, *Virtual Battlegrounds: Direct Participation in Cyber Warfare*, 9 J. L. &amp; POL’Y INFO. SOC’Y 1 (2013).\n TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 35, comment 5.\n *Id.* at Rule 30.\n *Id.* at Rule 35, comment 5.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n\nmissing is the threshold of harm at the first criterion.\nThe first criterion of the threshold of harm would also disqualify other cyber operations taken during an armed conflict. Cyber operations during an armed conflict that are taken for purely criminal or private reasons would not qualify as direct participation in hostilities. As an example, a criminal using cyber means to steal funds from a party to a conflict for purely personal gain, and not to negatively affect the party, would not be directly participating in hostilities. What is difficult about this example is that the party to the armed conflict would have to determine the intent of the civilian actor, which could be disguised as purely personal and criminal when it could in fact be aimed at adversely affecting the party to the conflict. Taken a step further, if the individual stole the money from the party in order to finance particular military operations, the operation to steal the money would be considered a direct participation in hostilities.\nPreparatory measures in cyberspace differ from those taken in the physical domain. Because civilians can be directly targeted for the duration of time during which they are directly participating in hostilities, it is important for parties to an armed conflict to understand the timeframe of direct participation. The actions taken in cyberspace immediately preceding or subsequent to a qualifying act of direct participation are included in the preparatory measures. As an example, a civilian travelling to and from the location of the computer he uses to mount a cyber operation would be included in the preparatory measures, and the civilian could be directly targeted in transit. The time for preparatory measures may even extend as far backward and forward in time as the causal link to the action exists. For example, in a cyber operation this would include the time when the civilian first starts to explore the vulnerabilities of the system of a party to an armed conflict, the time the individual creates the cyber tool to exploit the vulnerabilities, the period of time the civilian attacks the system, and through to the time the individual assesses\n TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, at Rule 35, comment 6.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id. at Rule 35, comment 7.\n Id.\n Id.\n\n[Vol. XLII\nthe damage to the system.\nIn addition to the preparatory measures taken for a cyber operation, parties to an armed conflict must take into account the delayed effects of direct participation in hostilities by civilians. The actions taken by civilians in the cyber domain have some parallels to the physical domain, but they also vary widely. The emplacement of a logic bomb, which is designed to activate at some point in the future upon either a command or after a predetermined period of time, is an example. The majority of the Tallinn Manual’s International Group of Experts takes the position that the time frame for which the civilian is directly participating, and can thus be targeted, is from the beginning of his involvement in mission planning until the individual terminates his active role in the operation. It is important to point out that the end of the period of direct participation may not sync up with the point when the damage occurs. For example, the first civilian may have created and emplaced the logic bomb, which is awaiting a command prompt to activate it. A second civilian may be the one to actually command the bomb to activate. In this example, the first civilian could have halted his period of direct participation and would no longer be directly targetable when the damage actually occurs. Thus, the key is for parties to determine when individuals are targetable based on when their participation begins and ends.\n## C. Determination of Direct Participation in Hostilities Complicated by Cyberspace-Specific Issues\nThe delayed effects of cyber operations complicate the accurate determination of precisely when a civilian is directly participating in cyber hostilities. The majority of the International Group of Experts takes the position that a civilian is directly participating in hostilities from the beginning of his involvement through the point in time where the civilian terminates an active role in the operation. The problem with this majority view is that it does not make clear to the participating civilian or to the\n TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, at Rule 35, comment 8.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id. at Rule 35, comment 6.\n\nState being attacked the window of time during which the civilian may be directly and legally targeted. The civilian may terminate an active role by no longer checking the status of the ongoing cyber operation, but the State may still attribute the operation to the civilian and target him. The State may not discover the ongoing cyber operation until after the civilian has terminated an active role, but the State has no way of knowing the civilian has terminated his active role in the ongoing cyber operation.\nThe logic bomb example parallels civilian operations in the physical world. Coalition Forces fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan faced road-side improvised explosive devices (“IEDs”), which were responsible for causing death and injury to troops as well as damage to military objects. If a civilian was responsible for building, transporting, emplacing, and setting off the IED, the civilian could be targeted throughout the entire process. The beginning and end of the civilian’s direct participation in hostilities could be measured from the time he began sourcing parts for the bomb until the time he set off the IED and transited back from the bombsite. Similarly, the civilian responsible for the logic bomb in the aforementioned example could be targeted from the time he began creating the logic bomb until he commands the logic bomb to activate. However, technology in the cyber domain varies widely from technology in the physical domain.\nIn the cyber domain, individuals can create programs capable of running autonomously or semi-autonomously. A computer network attack (“CAN”) is defined as either a cyber, electronic, or physical attack against an information technology facility or against computer equipment. Most of these CNAs are carried out by cyber operations, which use malicious code to infect enemy computers in order to exploit weaknesses in software, system configuration, or computer security practices. Cyber operations also include the use of bots, or remotely, or semi-autonomously controlled programs infecting computers, as well as botnets, which perform espionage by transmitting data between themselves while\n *Id.* at Rule 35, comment 4 (providing that there is well-known, ongoing debate as to whether the assembly of an IED qualifies as direct participation in hostilities).\n See generally CLAY WILSON, COMPUTER ATTACK AND CYBERTERRORISM 3-11 (2009) (providing insight on different types of attacks against computers).\n *Id.*\n\n[Vol. XLII\nawaiting the final activation signal from the operator. Malicious programs, such as spyware and malware, attack by disrupting normal computer functions or by opening a back door for a remote operator to take control of the computer. Cyber operators have designed computer exploits which launch anonymously from thousands of infected computers and which produce waves of disruption to overwhelm the target of the operation. The technology allowing autonomous and semi-autonomous operations in cyberspace makes difficult the task of determining the beginning and ending points of direct participation by civilians.\nA minority of the Tallinn Manual Group of Experts would break down the various steps in cyber operations such as the emplacement of the logic bomb and its activation as separate acts of direct participation. Under this view, the civilian would only directly participate in hostilities in intermittent instances when he is actively engaged in hostilities. This view provides greater protection to civilians, as they are shielded from directly being targeted except for the times when they are actively engaged in cyber operations. However, this view would make it very difficult for the parties engaged in armed conflict to accurately determine when civilians are directly participating and then target the civilians participating in hostilities at precisely those times. The Group of Experts is split regarding repeated cyber operations. One view is in line with the ICRC in that each cyber act must be treated separately in terms of direct participation analysis. On the other hand, another view is that it would make more operational sense if direct participation begins with the first cyber operation and continues throughout the period of intermittent activity. The latter view removes the “revolving door” effect and simplifies target ability by making the intermittent activity a singular, start-to-finish cyber operation.\n\nThe Tallinn Experts were also divided over the issue of presumption against direct participation. Recall that the Tallinn Manual provides that in cases where there is doubt as to whether an individual is a civilian, that individual should be treated like a civilian. The policy behind this principle is to ensure that civilians are protected to the utmost extent during armed conflicts. Some Tallinn Experts take this same line of thinking regarding civilians believed to be directly participating in hostilities. These experts believe civilians in this predicament should be given the benefit of the doubt.\nHowever, other Tallinn Experts take the position that when there is doubt as to whether a civilian is directly participating in hostilities, the attacking state must review the relevant information available and act reasonably in the circumstances in determining whether to conduct the attack. The policy behind this method rests in the attacking state’s ability to identify which targets are legal targets based on a reasonable review of the available information. The importance of these two views cannot be understated. Some experts side with protecting civilians to the maximum extent possible, while others favor the States’ ability to act while following LOAC principles.\nAlthough the Tallinn Manual agrees with ICRC Guidance’s requirements of a threshold of harm—a causal link between the action and the harm and a belligerent nexus—generally, the Tallinn Manual’s application of the ICRC’s guidance is a variation of the ICRC’s direct participation in hostilities legal regime involving cyber actions. The Tallinn manual does not have a requirement for physical damage to objects, so actions that may not qualify as cyber-attacks may still satisfy the criterion for the threshold of harm if the action has negatively affected the targeted State. Specifically, the Tallinn Manual provides that a civilian’s\n Id. at Rule 35, comment 12.\n TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, at Rule 33.\n Id. at Rule 35, comment 12.\n Id.\n Id.\n See Collin Allan, Direct Participation in Hostilities from Cyberspace, 50 VA. J. INT’L L. 174, 178 (2013) (explaining that “an act “must be specifically designed to directly cause the required threshold of harm in support of a party to the conflict and to the detriment of another”).\n Id. at 181 (explaining that “[as] long as an action inflicts, or has the objective\n\n[Vol. XLII]\naction which is carried out with only the intent of negatively affecting the adversary State’s military operations or to inflict death, physical harm, or material destruction on persons or objects is sufficient to show the threshold of harm. Furthermore, the majority of Tallinn experts agreed that interfering with an object’s functionality would rise to the level of destruction if a physical component must be replaced. Thus, the Tallinn view of the first-prong requirement of the threshold of harm may be seen as lowering the standard for what is required for civilians to be directly participating in hostilities.\nThe Tallinn Manual’s view of the second prong, which is the causal link between the act and the harm likely to result, also differs slightly from the ICRC Guidance. In particular, the Tallinn Manual focuses on the intended harm. By focusing on the intended harm, the Tallinn Manual may be lowering the standard of what is required for a civilian to participate in hostilities by looking at the civilian’s intent, rather than focusing on the likelihood of harm from the cyber operation. For example, a civilian may be directly targeted under the Tallinn Manual view for his role in assembling and storing the cyber equivalent of an IED because the individual intends the same harm as the person arming and detonating it. By comparing the Tallinn Manual’s view with the ICRC Guidance, it is possible that the Tallinn Manual lowers the standards for what is required for civilians to be directly participating in cyber hostilities. Therefore, civilians participating in hostilities through cyber means may be targetable in more situations than under the ICRC framework.\n## V. Drawing Distinctions between Government Civilian\nlikelihood of inflicting, death, injury, or destruction on protected people or objects, it will satisfy the threshold of harm requirement”).\n *Id.* at 182 (explaining that “[w]hereas the Interpretive Guidance applies an objective likelihood of the attack standard, the Tallinn Manual’s bar focuses on the civilian’s intent to carry out the attack”).\n *TALLINN MANUAL*, supra note 52, Rule 30, comment 10.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n See Allan, supra note 179, at 181.\n *Id.* at 186.\n *Id.* at 182.\n *Id.*\n\n# Employees and Contractors as against Non-State-Affiliated Civilians who Participate in Hostilities\nInternational humanitarian law defines civilians using negative terms. That is, they are defined as neither members of the armed forces, which includes groups assimilated to the armed forces such as organized armed groups, nor those participating in a levée en masse. Essentially, all others are considered civilians. Private contractors and employees of a party to an armed conflict who fit the definition of civilians are entitled to protection from being directly targeted, unless they are directly participating in hostilities. In addition, private contractors and civilian employees are not entitled to combatant immunity, as they are not members of the armed force. The activities carried out by contractors and employees as well as their location of duty may expose them to an increased risk of death or injury even if they are not directly participating in hostilities.\n## A. State-Affiliated Civilians\nModern warfare is increasingly dependent upon private contractors and civilian employees to fill a variety of positions traditionally held by military personnel. Generally, these private contractors and civilian employees are considered civilians under the same criteria that would apply to other civilians. That is, they cannot be directly targeted by a party to the armed conflict unless and for so long as they directly participate in hostilities. Due to the special roles of private contractors and civilian employees and their proximity to armed forces in hostilities, parties to an armed conflict must make determinations regarding attacks with particular care and due consideration.\nThe majority of private contractors and civilian employees have been incorporated into State armed forces, but they do not\n---\n See generally TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, Rule 29 (quoting the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 Aug. 1949, and Relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts art. 50, § 1, June 8, 1977, 1125 U.N.T.S. 3).\n Melzer, supra note 90.\n Id. at 38.\n Id. at 37.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id.\n\n[Vol. XLII\nperform functions that would have them directly participate in hostilities. Nevertheless, there are some contractor and civilians filling roles that would put them in situations where they could be seen as directly participating in hostilities. For example, private contractors and civilian employees that defend the base from attack could either be directly participating in hostilities or filling a law enforcement and defense-of-others role.\nEven if they have accompanied armed forces, private contractors and civilians were never meant to (and should never be allowed to) directly participate in hostilities on behalf of a party to a conflict. As long as they are not incorporated into armed forces, private contractors and civilian employees do not cease to be civilians, and they do not lose their civilian protection simply because they accompany armed forces. Moreover, they do not lose their civilian protection just because they assume functions other than conducting hostilities, which traditionally would have been performed by members of armed forces. Contractors and civilian employees who directly participate in hostilities without the express authorization of the party to the armed conflict remain civilians, but they lose their protection from being directly targeted. Contractors and employees can lose their civilian status if they have been incorporated into the armed forces of a party to a conflict. If this happens, the contractors and employees would become members of an organized armed force under the command responsible for the party to the conflict and would no longer qualify as civilians.\n---\n See Melzer, *supra* note 90, at 37 (explaining the basic notion of direct participation in hostilities).\n See *id.* at 44 (illustrating that “[t]he notion of direct participation in hostilities does not refer to a person’s status, function, or affiliation, but to his or her engagement in specific hostile acts”).\n *Id.* at 38.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n See Melzer, *supra* note 90, at 39 (explaining that “[a]s long as they are not incorporated into the armed forces, private contractors and civilian employees do not cease to be civilians simply because they accompany the armed forces and or assume functions other than the conduct of hostilities that would traditionally have been performed by military personnel”).\n *Id.*\n\nThe Tallinn Manual’s international group of experts concurs that individual contractors and civilians may only be directly targeted based on their direct participation in hostilities during an armed conflict. However, there are issues that arise in cyberspace regarding the use of contractors and civilians to perform specific military operations. Unlike traditional warfare, where almost all military operations were carried out by troops and equipment, modern warfare introduces the use of cyber capabilities which conduct a portion of the military operations. An example is the hiring of a private company by a party to an armed conflict that is later contracted to perform specific military operations. Based on the military operations, the company would qualify as an organized armed group belonging to the party to the conflict. Therefore, the civilians employed as private contractors would be considered belonging to the organized armed group. However, even if the civilians were not to be considered as belonging to the organized armed group, they would still only be directly targetable when and if they are directly participating in hostilities.\nCivilian government employees are also employed in positions requiring them to conduct cyber operations during an armed conflict, such as positions within an intelligence agency. If the group of civilians conducting cyber operations qualifies as an organized armed group, the civilian members are subject to attack regardless of direct participation in hostilities. Otherwise, the civilian employees are only directly targetable when they are directly participating in hostilities. As a result, the historic view of citizens carrying out actions typically performed by members of armed forces may be problematic when analyzing the cyber domain construct. The traditional view of warfare holds that private contractors and civilian employees operating in an organized armed group, affiliated with armed forces in an armed conflict, would not be entitled to combatant status.\n\n[Vol. XLII]\nFurthermore, a party to the armed conflict employing civilians to perform intelligence functions, attack execution, or other CNA operations would violate the law of war. The reasoning behind this view is that only members of armed forces or assimilated organizations are granted combatant status because they meet the following conditions: (i) they are commanded by a person responsible for his subordinates; (ii) they have a fixed distinctive emblem recognizable at distance; (iii) they carry arms openly; and (iv) they conduct their operation in accordance with the laws and customs of war. Accordingly, under the traditional view, parties to an armed conflict should employ members of the armed force to carry out CNA functions, and if they desire contractors or civilian employees to fill these roles, then the parties should incorporate them into the regular armed forces.\nDue to the vastly different landscape and operations carried out in cyberspace as opposed to the physical domain, a suggested course of action would be to rely less on the aforementioned four conditions and instead look to state affiliation. The four criteria from the 1874 Brussels Declaration apply perfectly to traditional warfare, but operations in cyberspace are conducted without the need of having a fixed recognizable emblem or of carrying arms openly. By requiring state affiliation for civilian employees, it preserves concern for the principle of distinction in CNA from the Brussels criteria. States employing civilians to conduct cyber operations are less likely to be doing so to prevent the enemy from attacking the civilians. Instead, States are likely taking advantage of the economic, training, and recruiting advantages that develop as a result of not being limited to armed forces filling these behind-the-lines roles. The fact that cyber operations take\nON CYBER CONFLICT, 235, 242 (2012), https://ccdcoe.org/cycon/2012/proceedings/d2r1s10_watts.pdf [https://perma.cc/X6F2-TTRP] [hereinafter Notion of Combatancy].\n Id.\n See id. at 245 (citing the Project of an International Declaration Concerning the Laws and Customs of War, Aug. 27, 1874, 4 Martens Nouveau Recueil (ser. 2) 219 (“1874 Brussels Declaration”)).\n Id.\n Id.\n Id.\n See Notion of Combatancy, supra note 210, at 246.\n Id.\n\nplace far from the battlefield also bolsters the position of state affiliation, because there is no concern that the enemy will be confused regarding distinction in targeting.\nUnder the state affiliation view of civilians taking part in cyber operations, discipline in warfare will continue to be preserved as it is under the four Brussels criteria. Currently, civilians directly participating in hostilities are not subject to the internal military disciplinary system. However, the well-developed legal regimes that prosecute and punish war crimes operate in a manner to vindicate concerns for discipline and humanity. In addition to international enforcement bodies, domestic criminal codes now serve as mechanisms where civilians are equally susceptible to prosecution for any war crimes they have committed. Under the state-affiliation view, States will be able to employ civilians to conduct cyber operations while enabling combatant status. States will also be able to maintain the critically important notions of distinction and discipline as provided under the four Brussels criteria.\nStates employing private contractors and civilian employees do so because of the different landscape and types of operations carried out in cyberspace. As they are written and observed, current LOAC principles, ICRC guidance, and the Tallinn Manual hold that civilians operating in cyberspace in a way that directly participates in hostilities are subject to directly being targeted but are not given combatant immunity. The view of letting state-affiliation drive combatant status determinations for cyberspace operations provides civilians with combatant status, or a version of it, while parties to an armed conflict can still conduct warfare and be no worse off. Currently, parties to an armed conflict operating in cyberspace are left with the difficult task of making determinations regarding direct participation in hostilities by civilians operating anonymously. The state-affiliation view would, at the least, put civilians on notice of what their consequences of participation entail, as well as protect them by\n\n[Vol. XLII]\ngiving them some version of combatant immunity for their actions in armed conflict.\nA comparison of state-affiliated actors versus non-state-affiliated actors may lead to different statuses for each. When viewed as either contractors, who are working on behalf of a State engaged in an international armed conflict, or hacktivists, who operate outside of the control of the State but engage in cyber operations in favor of the State, the statuses of each may be seen as divergent. While neither of the two would qualify for combatant immunity, based on the four requirements provided by the Third Geneva Convention, contractors would have the best shot at being entitled prisoner-of-war (“POW”) status. Due to the nature of their service, contractors accompanying an armed force likely carry identification cards associating them with the armed force. Accordingly, contractors would not be given combatant status, but they would be more likely than hacktivists to be given POW status.\nCivilians accompanying armed forces are afforded some protection, but that protection comes with the inherent danger of accompanying armed forces. State-affiliated civilians qualifying for the narrow category of “civilians accompanying the armed forces” could be eligible for POW status while at the same time also be legitimate military targets for the enemy State. These civilians would likely be performing duties in the functional category of operating and maintaining the cyber operations systems. The majority of the participation by a state-affiliated civilian cyber scientist would be viewed as indirect participation. However, there are possible situations where a civilian’s particular expertise could have an exceptional and potentially decisive value for the outcome of an armed conflict. An example would be a computer programmer who researches and writes attack programs, one of which is used to incapacitate the enemy’s network controlling the launch of weapons systems. In this example, the civilian scientist could be responsible for the turning point in the conflict, thus shifting his participation from indirect to direct. The importance of this example is that the State hosting the state-affiliated civilian and the civilian need to understand the possible implications of having the scientist participate, directly or indirectly, in hostilities. Further, the enemy State is going to have to make a call as to whether it can directly target the civilian scientist or attack the military target and consider the scientist collateral damage.\n## B. Non-State-Affiliated Civilians\nNon-state-affiliated civilians, also known as patriotic hackers or hacktivists, are the civilians directly participating in hostilities armed forces’ (presumably those who operate and maintain those systems)—even if they do not actually press the button that launches a cyberattack—are both eligible for prisoner-of-war status and also legitimate military targets for the enemy”).\n *Id.*\n *See id.* at 291–92 (stating that “there is a high probability that many, if not most, of the personnel substantively involved in cyber operations may actually be civilians”).\n *See id.* at 292 (discussing that “[c]omputer technicians, technical maintenance personnel and others who perform similar tasks . . . could thus qualify for inclusion in the limited category of ‘persons who accompany the armed forces without actually being members thereof’”).\n *See id.* at 291 (distinguishing computer programmers who research and write attack programs from operators who execute cyber attacks).\n Turns, *supra* note 62, at 291.\n\n[Vol. XLII]\non their own volition, so they will likely receive no protection under LOAC. These hackers carry out cyber operations against perceived enemy computer systems, without the control or oversight from their government but seek common political ends. Hacktivists would seem to receive no protection due to their direct participation in hostilities; however, hacktivists could arguably be considered participants in a *levée en masse* if they took up arms spontaneously upon the enemy approaching, lack organization, and carried arms openly. If so, hacktivists would be entitled to POW status, but they could be directly targeted while directly participating in hostilities. The LOAC principles have not been updated for cyber operations, so it is difficult to play out exactly how non-state-affiliated civilians are to be treated during international armed conflicts. Ideally, IHL would be universally understood by states engaged in armed conflict and the non-state-affiliated civilians who choose to directly participate in cyber hostilities would be on notice as to how their actions will be measured.\nAlso, made difficult by the landscape and types of operations carried out in cyberspace is the direct targeting of those individuals directly participating. Aside from anonymity being a difficult hurdle in cyberspace, the determination as to whether a physical attack is justified in response to a cyber action is still theoretical. Furthermore, neither treaties nor customary international law have established the illegality of espionage, either in the physical world or in cyberspace. Thus, civilians conducting CNAs on behalf of a State which is party to an armed conflict may not be directly participating in hostilities. Further, customary international law has not recognized data manipulation and deletions as rising to the level of hostilities, so civilians conducting these types of CNAs would not be directly participating in hostilities.\n## VI. Suggested Treatment For Non-State-Affiliated Civilians\n *Id.* at 293.\n *See id.* (explaining that hacktivists could arguably be assimilated to the rarely used category of *levée en masse*, in which case they would be entitled to POW status if captured, and could also be subject to attack while acting as such a body; [i]n order to meet the legal conditions of a *levée en masse* they would have to “take up arms” spontaneously “on the approach of the enemy”).\n *See id.* (explaining the difficulty of applying the criteria necessary to meet the legal conditions of a *levée en masse* in a cyber-conflict).\n\n# Directly Participating In Cyber Hostilities\nThe principles of LOAC, as they currently exist, govern actions taken in cyberspace as if they occur in the more traditional, physical domain. A major concern with this LOAC application is the effect it has on civilians. As the law of war has evolved, the protection of civilians has been one of the key tenets from the outset. The Fourth Geneva Convention sought to protect civilian persons taking no part in hostilities as well as the wounded and sick. The Convention also prohibited an occupying power from destroying real and personal property belonging to civilians. The Additional Protocol I of the Geneva Convention calls for the protection of civilians from unnecessary injury or death and obliges combatants to distinguish themselves from the civilian population while engaged in an attack. The civilian population is specifically protected under Part IV, which demands the parties to at all times distinguish between civilian population and combatants as well as between civilian objects and military objectives. Further, Protocol I prohibits parties from making the civilian population the object of an attack, which also prohibits acts or threats having the intent to terrorize the civilian population.\nThe protections provided by LOAC are two-fold. On one hand, they are meant to inform parties to an armed conflict regarding how to conduct themselves while at war. On the other hand, LOAC provides notice to civilians affected by armed conflict as to the treatment they can expect from the parties to the conflict. The relative nuance of cyberspace operations, as compared to traditional warfare, makes difficult the determination of direct participation in hostilities by citizens. If LOAC principles are incapable of adequately putting parties to armed conflict and citizens on notice, it should be amended for this purpose.\n Geneva Convention, supra note 2, art. 15.\n Id.\n Id. art. 44.\n Protocol I, supra note 1, art. 48.\n Id. art. 51.\n\n[Vol. XLII\n## A. Temporal Considerations in the Cyber Domain\nDirect participation in hostilities by civilians operating in the cyber domain is vastly different than participation in the physical domain due to temporal considerations. Actions taken in cyberspace are not easily detected as they are happening, and they are often created for use in the future. For example, computer network attacks involve the use of malicious code to either infect an enemy’s computer system or to exploit weaknesses in the software, system configuration, or security practices. Additionally, bots and even botnets are remotely-controlled or semi-autonomous computer programs that infect computers and systems to transmit data obtained by the system or instruct the system to operate a certain way. Hackers have even designed ways to exploit computers and systems in a way to launch programs anonymously and autonomously from thousands of infected computers. Accordingly, cyber operations differ greatly from physical operations due to the timing of how the operations are carried out. Cyber operations can be set to take place at a certain time in the future or after a certain event has occurred.\nThe ICRC Guidance and the Tallinn Manual both touch on these temporal considerations. The ICRC provides that preparatory acts can be treated as separate acts and distinguished from the act that is the object of the direct participation in hostilities. Therefore, a civilian participating in hostilities may\n See WILSON, supra note 163, at 39 (explaining the characteristics of malicious code).\n Id. at 38 (explaining that “[a]utomated programs, or ‘bots’ . . . are increasingly autonomous, rapid, and difficult to detect . . . [and] can be remotely controlled by commands sent through the Internet and can be activated to operate in a coordinated manner on thousands of computers in different locations around the world”); see id. at 41 (explaining that “[s]ome compromised computers become part of an automatic ‘bot network,’ quietly performing espionage by transmitting data or intermediate preparatory instructions back and forth between compromised computers while awaiting a special final activation signal originating from the attacker”).\n See id. at 43 (explaining that “hackers have also designed recent computer exploits that launch anonymously from thousands of infected computers to produce waves of disruption that can quickly overwhelm a targeted organization, or multiple organizations such as a list of banking institutions”).\n See Melzer, supra note 90, at 68 (stating that “[w]here the execution of a hostile act does not require geographic displacement, as may be the case with computer network attacks or remote-controlled weapons systems, the duration of direct participation in\n\nconduct a series of acts, each directly participating in hostilities, over a period of time that lead up to the object of the direct participation. The Tallinn Manual provides that the scope of direct participation includes the actions immediately preceding and those subsequent to the qualifying act of direct participation in hostilities. The majority of the Tallinn Experts agree that a civilian is directly targetable only for the duration of the direct participation in hostilities, regardless of when the actual effects are realized. Yet, some of the experts take the position that the time period during which a civilian can be directly targeted extends for as long as there is a causal link to the intended harm. That is, a civilian is targetable as far upstream and as far downstream as that civilian’s causal link exists between the action taken and the intended harm. As an example, a civilian may be targeted as early as when he begins a cyber operation by probing the enemy’s system and carry through to when he conducts the cyber operation against the system. The civilian may even be targeted after the cyber operation, when he is conducting a damage assessment and determining whether to conduct another operation against the system.\nThese temporal considerations are worth exploring because they mostly exist only in the cyber context. Accordingly, there may be a disconnect between how States view cyber operations versus operations in the physical world due to the way LOAC principles were developed for the physical world. Though it is possible to parallel these temporal considerations by discussing IEDs emplaced for the destruction of the enemy State’s equipment and the injury of its people, there is not a precise match. While IEDs can be emplaced with the intent of them going off in the future upon being activated, IEDs with this setup cannot be controlled and changed like their logic bomb counterpart in the cyber world. Applying LOAC principles to an IED would yield\n TALLINN MANUAL, *supra* note 52, at Rule 35, comment 7.\n *Id.* at Rule 35, comment 8.\n *Id.* at Rule 35, comment 7.\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n\n[Vol. XLII\nthe bomb maker likely being targetable while building the bomb, based on his intent, and the civilian emplacing the IED being targetable while emplacing the IED. It would not be as clean cut in the cyber world based on the ability of the logic bomb builder and the one who activates it to carry out the entire operation in complete anonymity as well as being able to control the logic bomb once it is emplaced.\nFor the sake of clarifying the discussion below, the civilians being discussed are non-state-affiliated civilians. State-affiliated civilians are those who operate as either private contractors on behalf of the State or as civilian employees, who are employed by the State. These civilians are better aware of their exposure to direct attack based on the nature of their service, which could include operational as well as geographic proximity to armed forces. Thus, the State and the state-affiliated civilians are on notice as to whether and for how long the civilians may be directly targeted by the opposing state during an armed conflict.\nAdditional Protocol I provides that civilians and civilian populations enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations. However, civilians forfeit this protection if and for so long as they directly participate in hostilities. Direct participation by civilians in cyberspace is not always clear. The International Group of Experts was split regarding repeated cyber operations by civilians that qualified as direct participation in hostilities. Some of the experts side with ICRC guidance, which provides that each act must be treated separately as separate acts of direct participation. Other experts conclude separate direct participation analysis made little operational sense and believe it would create a “revolving door” effect regarding targetability. This group of experts believes direct participation by the civilian begins with the first cyber operation he participates in and continues throughout the period of intermittent activity. This incongruent application of existing LOAC principles on cyberspace operations demonstrates the potential for civilians and\n Protocol I, supra note 1, art. 51.\n Id.\n TALLINN MANUAL, supra note 52, Rule 35, comment 7.\n Id.\n Id.\n Id.\n\nparties to an armed conflict to misapply or misinterpret LOAC principles.\nWhat if a non-state-affiliated civilian were to create an autonomous logic bomb and release it with the intent to infiltrate and attack the computer network of the defense ministry of a State which is party to an ongoing armed conflict? At what point could the civilian be targeted by the State? If the State discovers the logic bomb months after it was released by the civilian, and assuming the State can attribute it to the civilian, can the State target the civilian then? Under ICRC guidance, the civilian could be directly targeted for each act of direct participation in hostilities. Accordingly, the civilian could be directly attacked when producing the logic bomb with the intent to launch a CNA against the State, if done so in support of another party to the conflict, and when the civilian actually launches the logic bomb. However, ICRC guidance would not likely support a direct attack against the civilian if discovered months after it was launched. Under the Tallinn Manual’s viewpoint, the civilian may be directly targeted.\nAs discussed above, it may be unclear to civilians directly participating in hostilities in the cyber domain as to how their actions could be interpreted by parties to an armed conflict. Aside from civilians conducting intermittent direct participation in hostilities in cyberspace, civilians may also be unclear as to their exposure for direct targeting due to the uncertain application of LOAC principles to the cyber domain. Specifically, civilians launching autonomous or semi-autonomous programs to attack computer networks may directly participate in hostilities by building the code and program for the specific purpose as well as directly participate by launching the CNA. However, these civilians may at some point decide they no longer wish to pursue the action against a party to an armed conflict.\n JEAN-MARIE HENCKAERTS &amp; LOUISE DOSWALD-BECK, CUSTOMARY INTERNATIONAL HUMANITARIAN LAW VOL. 1: RULES 1, 21 (2005).\n Id.\n Id. at 23.\n Turns, supra note 62, at 281.\n\n[Vol. XLII\n## B. Change of Heart for Civilians Directly Participating in Cyber Hostilities\nHow might a civilian make clear to a State embroiled in an armed conflict that the civilian who conducted a cyber operation against the State no longer wishes to directly participate in cyber hostilities? In the physical domain, the civilian would simply stop shooting at the party, collecting arms to use against the party, building bombs to emplace in roadways, or collecting money to finance attacks against the party to the conflict. An example which could parallel the cyber domain would be a civilian bomb maker who makes a bomb and emplaces that bomb in a road in an effort to target a party to an armed conflict. However, the bomb maker could make clear his intentions to no longer directly participate by putting up a sign warning of the bomb, digging up the bomb, or telling the party the location of the bomb. In cyberspace, a civilian who creates the malicious code for the CNA and launches it may not be able to recall the code or stop the cyber operation once it has begun. Once the malicious code is discovered, the targeted State may attack the civilian because it is impossible to precisely determine if the civilian has stopped directly participating in cyber hostilities. The State could argue the civilian is still monitoring and directing the logic bomb or malicious code.\nThe advanced technology which enables civilians to directly participate in hostilities could make it difficult for both the civilian and the party to the armed conflict to know when the civilian is no longer directly participating. The civilian who produces the malicious code for a CNA concludes his direct participation when he stops working on or even finishes the code. Would the civilian who launches the malicious code for a CNA conclude his direct participation when the code is launched? What if the malicious code were autonomous or semi-autonomous, and it would continue to operate without the aid from the civilian? This would seem to be a magic bullet fired in the physical world. In the physical domain, the bullet would lose speed and fall to the earth. However, malicious code launched in the cyber domain may\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n *Id.*\n\ncontinue until it is discovered and counter by the attacked party or until it reaches its termination stage, if it has one. May the civilian launching this code be directly targeted until the malicious code ceases to operate as part of the CNA?\nCurrent interpretations by the ICRC and the International Group of Experts contributing to the Tallinn Manual apply IHL to the cyber domain and determine that the civilian launching the CNA code can only be targeted so long as he is directly participating in hostilities, which is when he is actively engaged. The ICRC and the Group of Experts are unwilling to extend the window of targetability to include ongoing hostilities set in motion by the individual unleashing the malicious code aimed at conducting a CNA. As previously stated in the magic bullet analogy, there is nothing to stop the CNA code except for the initiator, unless the attacked State becomes aware of the CNA and takes steps to defend against it. Accordingly, should not the attacked State be able to target the civilian initiator after he has set in motion the CNA? If the State is able to stretch the targetability window to legally target the initiating civilian so long as the CNA is underway, can the civilian limit his exposure in any way?\nA solution might be found in the American Law Institute’s Model Penal Code (“MPC”). The MPC defines criminal conspiracy as a person conspiring with another person or group of persons to commit a crime if the individual, with the purpose of promoting or facilitating the crime: 1) agrees with the other person or group that one or more of them will engage in conduct constituting a crime; or 2) agrees to aid the other person or group in planning or committing the crime. However, the actor may, after having conspired to commit a crime, use as an affirmative defense the fact that the actor thwarted the success of the conspiracy after having manifested a complete and voluntary renunciation of his criminal purpose. By renouncing his support for the crime and thwarting the success of the conspiracy, the actor is able to undo the effort he put into conspiring to commit the crime.\n Eva Knopova, *New IHL Framework for Cyber Warfare: Master’s Thesis*, CHARLES UNIV. PRAGUE DEP’T INT’L L. 47 (2016).\n Id.\n American Law Institute, *MODEL PENAL CODE § 5.03* (Tent. Draft No. 4, 1955).\n Id.\n\n[Vol. XLII]\nAs applied to the above issue regarding civilians directly participating in cyber hostilities, a civilian putting into place malicious code capable of autonomously conducting a CNA may be able to be certain he cannot be directly targeted by the party to an armed conflict by renouncing his support for the cyber hostilities and working to thwart further cyber hostilities by the code. By attempting to prevent future direct targeting, the civilian may inadvertently leave himself exposed to attack by making his actions and identity known to the party. However, a party to an armed conflict abiding by LOAC would not be able to target a civilian who is no longer participating in hostilities. Further, the civilian may take similar actions to renounce his participation and thwart further action by the code in an anonymous way.\nBy adopting this view, States who are a party to an armed conflict have better ground rules as to how to legally target non-state-affiliated civilians who are participating in cyber hostilities in a way that may not be covered by current IHL. Additionally, under this view, civilians will have a better understanding of how their actions, carried out as cyber operations, will be treated by States who are a party to an armed conflict. This view provides States and civilians with notice of how actions by civilians will be treated in cyberspace. Further, this view provides civilians who have participated in cyber hostilities, and who may be determined to be still participating based on the autonomous CNA code the individual initiated, an opportunity to remove themselves from hostilities. By taking steps discussed in the MPC to remove oneself from a conspiracy, the initiating individual can undo the bonds currently opening himself up to being targeted by a party to the conflict.\nBy coming forward, renouncing his support for the ongoing cyber hostilities, and attempting to thwart the object of the cyber\n HENCKAERTS &amp; DOSWALD-BECK, supra note 260, at 19–20.\n See generally INT’L &amp; OPERATIONAL L. DEP’T., THE JUDGE ADVOCATE GEN.’S LEGAL CTR. &amp; SCH., U.S. ARMY, LAW OF ARMED CONFLICT DESKBOOK, 7 (2015) (explaining that “[o]nly combatants or those directly participating in hostilities may be targeted . . . [n]on-combatants, including civilians and persons out of combat, may not intentionally be targeted”).\n HENCKAERTS &amp; DOSWALD-BECK, supra note 260, at 19–20.\n American Law Institute, supra note 269.\n\noperation, a civilian may prevent the targeted State from directly targeting the civilian. However, the civilian may also be creating an unexpected repercussion. The civilian directly taking part in cyber hostilities, favoring a party to an armed conflict by conducting cyber operations against an opponent party, also exposes himself to domestic criminal law pertaining to the cyber operations. By coming forward, the civilian may be opening himself up to prosecution under domestic criminal law in an effort to prevent being directly targeted by the State against whom the civilian directly participated in hostilities. This may create a disincentive for civilians to expose themselves as ongoing direct participants in cyber hostilities, but the damage is already done.\nThe only question that remains is attribution. Can the attacked State determine who the civilian is for either direct targeting purposes or domestic criminal prosecution? If the civilian believes so, the civilian could limit his exposure to being directly attacked as well as request leniency from the domestic criminal prosecution for his cooperation. The alternative is for the civilian to figure out a way to completely remove every trace of his participation in an ongoing cyber operation, thereby ensuring the attacked State does not discover the cyber operation, attribute it to the civilian, and directly attack him.\nWithout this possible outlet, civilians who have had a change of heart and no longer wish to participate in cyber hostilities may be targeted in the future for previous participation in cyber hostilities, of which they no longer wish to be a part. Though not a perfect method for keeping civilians safe from being directly targeted, this method provides notice to the attacking State of the civilian’s previous acts, which are the acts the civilian no longer wishes to be held accountable for in the realm of armed conflict. The civilian’s renouncing of previous participation in hostilities will not absolve him of domestic law implications, but it will ensure he is not targeted in the future.\n\n[Vol. XLII]\n# VII. Conclusion\nCivilians directly participate in hostilities for numerous reasons. State-affiliated civilians might engage in direct participation as part of their job; non-state-affiliated civilians might directly participate out of a sense of patriotism, helping the underdog, or feeling like part of the fight. Cyberspace creates an environment unlike any other ever seen before, so civilians and States who are a party to an armed conflict struggle to understand how LOAC principles apply to their conduct. A misunderstanding by a civilian could lead to a prolonged period of being directly targeted by a party to a conflict; a misunderstanding by that party could lead to allegations of war crimes. All sides to a conflict, to include civilians, would benefit from consensus in the application of LOAC to the cyber domain.\nA consensus in the application of LOAC principles in the cyber domain could lead to stronger footing for States and citizens as the cyberspace domain becomes a larger battleground. Cyberspace issues such as anonymity, attribution, temporal considerations, and equal application of force between the physical and cyber domains all highlight the need to better define LOAC applications to the cyber domain. Specifically, civilians should be able to renounce their direct participation in cyber hostilities, and they should no longer face direct targeting by a party to a conflict for cyber operations taken previously. The Tallinn Manual spells out that civilians may be directly targeted so long as their causal link to the action exists. States subscribing to this view may link civilians to cyber operations carried out previously, even after civilians have walked away and no longer desire to directly participate.\nThe ability to target civilians for previous acts of cyber hostilities when States believe a causal link still exists may lead to an expanded window of time during which a civilian may be targeted. Thus, States who are party to a conflict should be able to know with certainty that the civilian they intend to target is a lawful target, due to the civilian’s ongoing intent to directly participate in hostilities. The renunciation clause found in the Model Penal Code could be the solution to ending\n Turns, supra note 62, at 281.\n Id.\n\nmisunderstandings by civilians and parties to a conflict regarding direct participation and targeting.\nUnder this view, civilians have a way to guarantee they will no longer be directly targeted for past cyber operations amounting to direct participation in hostilities when the State may not know the civilian’s participation has concluded. In addition, this view provides an out for States directly targeting civilians for directly participating in cyber hostilities against the State because the civilian has the opportunity and incentive to come clean if the civilian no longer wishes to directly participate. By coming forward, civilians may open themselves up to domestic prosecution, but they guarantee they will not be directly targeted by a State.\nA final point is examined by asking: should civilians have to go to such lengths to ensure they will not be directly targeted by a State for previous instances of direct participation in hostilities? Further, should LOAC require citizens to take active steps to put States on notice as to the citizens’ activities to prevent being illegally targeted after the direct participation in hostilities has concluded? An argument can be made that this policy would be requiring too much of civilians, and it exposes civilians to a lose-lose scenario.\nOn the one hand, civilians want to ensure the temporal anomalies in the cyber domain do not mislead States into falsely believing civilians are continuing to directly participate in hostilities after participation has ended. On the other, civilians want to protect against domestic prosecution and initiating an investigation into their activities. Though a possible solution to the issue of civilians being overly or illegally targeted could be found in the Model Penal Code, international law may not be willing to support the process or potential side effects to civilians providing notice to States that the civilians have withdrawn from the direct participation in hostilities.\n\n^{}[]",

      "flat_text": "HEINONLINE\n-- Your use of this HeinOnline PDF indicates your acceptance of HeinOnline's Terms and\n# The Targeting of Non-State-Affiliated Civilians in Cyberspace: Lagging LOAC Principles Cause Uncertainty on Both Sides\nJames Emory Tucker, Jr.†\nI. Introduction ... 1014\nII. The Treatment of Civilians in Traditional Warfare ... 1015\nA. Geneva Convention and the Additional Protocol ... 1016\nB. Civilians Directly Participating in Hostilities ... 1018\nIII. The Current Treatment of Civilians in the Cyberspace Domain ... 1021\nA. Cyber Operations and the Law of Armed Conflict ... 1022\nB. The Objects of Cyber Attacks ... 1026\nIV. Civilians Directly Participating in Hostilities in the Cyberspace Domain ... 1028\nA. Defining Direct Participation in Hostilities ... 1029\nB. Tallinn Manual View of Direct Participation in Hostilities ... 1033\nC. Determination of Direct Participation in Hostilities Complicated by Cyberspace-Specific Issues ... 1036\nV. Drawing Distinctions between Government Civilian Employees and Contractors as against Non-State-Affiliated Civilians who Participate in Hostilities ... 1040\nA.
